SEARCH
Package remote

Class Service<T>

java.lang.Object
remote.Service<T>
Type Parameters:
T - The interface that the Service will handle method call requests for.

A Service encapsulates a multithreaded TCP server and allows connections from client Stubs that are created using the StubFactory.

The Service class is parametrized by a type variable. This type variable should be instantiated with an interface. The Service will accept calls from Stubs to invoke methods on this interface. It will then forward those requests to an instantiated Object, which is specified when the Service is constructed. The Object must implement the remote interface. Each method in the interface should be marked as throwing RemoteObjectException, in addition to any other exceptions as needed.

Exceptions may occur at the top level in the listening and service threads. The Service's response to these exceptions can be customized by deriving a class from Service and overriding listen_error or service_error.

public class Service<T> extends Object
Remote Object Service

  • Constructor Details

    • Service

      public Service(Class<T> c, T svc, int port)
      The first constructor creates a Service that is bound to a given remote interface, instantiated object, and server port number. This constructor is used when no loss or delay is desired for the network Sockets.
      Parameters:
      c - A representation of the class of the interface that the Service must handle method call requests for.
      svc - An instantiated object that implements the interface indicated by c. Upon receipt of requests for method calls, the Service invokes those calls on this object.
      Throws:
      Error - If c does not represent a remote interface, i.e., an interface whose methods all throw RemoteObjectException.
      NullPointerException - If either of c or svc is null.

    • Service

      public Service(Class<T> c, T svc, int port, boolean lossy, boolean delayed)
      The second constructor creates a Service similar to the first one, but with additional parameters to enable simulated loss and/or delay of Objects being sent over network Sockets.
      Parameters:
      c - A representation of the class of the interface that the Service must handle method call requests for.
      svc - An instantiated object that implements the interface indicated by c. Upon receipt of requests for method calls, the Service invokes those calls on this object.
      lossy - A flag that indicates whether or not Objects can be lost between sender and receiver, resulting in timeout.
      delayed - A flag that indicates whether propagation delay is incurred when sending an Object from sender to receiver.
      Throws:
      Error - If c does not represent a remote interface, i.e., an interface whose methods all throw RemoteObjectException.
      NullPointerException - If either of c or svc is null.

  • Method Details

    • isRunning

      public boolean isRunning()

    • isRemoteInterface

      private boolean isRemoteInterface(Class<T> c)
      Check if the provided interface is a remote interface.
      Parameters:
      c - The interface class to check.
      Returns:
      True if the interface is considered remote, false otherwise.

    • declaresRemoteObjectException

      private boolean declaresRemoteObjectException(Method method)
      Check if a method declares RemoteObjectException.
      Parameters:
      method - The method to check.
      Returns:
      True if the method declares RemoteObjectException, false otherwise.

    • stopped

      protected void stopped(Throwable cause)
      When the listening thread exits, it should call stopped.

      The parameter passed from the listening thread allows the Service to react accordingly, namely whether the thread stops due to an exception or a call to stop.

      When this method is called, the calling thread owns the lock on the Service object. Care must be taken to avoid deadlocks when calling start or stop from different threads during this call.

      The default implementation does nothing.

      Parameters:
      cause - The exception that stopped the Service, or null if the Service stopped normally.

    • listen_error

      protected boolean listen_error(Exception exception)
      When an exception occurs in the listening thread, it also calls listen_error.

      The intent of this method is to allow the user to report exceptions in the listening thread to another thread, by a mechanism of the user's choosing. The user may also ignore the exceptions. The default implementation simply stops the server. The user should not use this method to stop the Service. The exception will again be provided as the argument to stopped, which will be called later.

      Parameters:
      exception - The exception that occurred.
      Returns:
      true if the service should resume accepting connections, false if the service should shut down.

    • service_error

      protected void service_error(RemoteObjectException exception)
      When an exception occurs in a service thread, service_error is called, similar to previous.

      The default implementation does nothing.

      Parameters:
      exception - The exception that occurred.

    • start

      public void start() throws RemoteObjectException
      The Service is started using start.

      A thread is created to listen for connection requests on the port specified when the Service was constructed. The network address can be learned using suitable Socket APIs. After creating the listening thread, this method should return immediately.

      The synchronized keyword may need to be added, depending on the implementation.

      Throws:
      RemoteObjectException - When the listening socket cannot be created or bound, when the listening thread cannot be created, or when the server has already been started and has not since stopped.

    • listenForConnections

      private void listenForConnections()
      Listens for connection requests and handles them by creating new service threads.

      This method continuously listens for incoming connection requests as long as the service is running and the server socket has not been closed. For each connection request, it initializes a LeakySocket and starts a new Service<T>.ServiceThread to handle method invocation requests from the client.

      Note: This method is intended to be run in a separate thread and will exit when the service is stopped or when an unrecoverable error occurs.

    • stop

      public void stop()
      The Service is stopped using stop, if it is running.

      This terminates the listening thread and calls other methods as needed.

      The synchronized keyword may be needed, depending on the implementation.

    • getCount

      public int getCount()
